snippet: The food company General Mills added language to its website to alert customers that they cannot take legal action against the company if they download coupons, enter a contest or connect with it in other ways.
abstract: General Mills adds language to its website to alert consumers that they give up their right to sue the company if they interact with it online in a variety of ways, such as downloading coupons; company also suggests that buying its products would bind consumers to those terms; change makes General Mills one of the first, if not the first, major food company to impose so-called 'forced arbitration' on consumers.
lead_paragraph: The food company General Mills added language to its website to alert customers that they cannot take legal action against the company if they download coupons, enter a contest or connect with it in other ways.

headline.main: When ‘Liking’ a Brand Online Voids the Right to Sue
